headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for edition of July 11, 2017.

headline: Canadian Forest Fires Force Lumber Mills to Shut Down
summary: Raging forest fires across British Columbia have led three major lumber producers to suspend production, while more than 14,000 people have been ordered to evacuate.

headline: Soldier in Hawaii Charged With Support of ISIS
summary: A U.S. soldier stationed in Hawaii has been charged with providing material support to ISIS, according to a criminal complaint filed Monday in the U.S. District Court in Honolulu.

headline: News Publishers Team Up to Take On Facebook, Google
summary: Publishers are calling on the U.S. Congress to allow them to negotiate collectively with Google and Facebook, as the duo increasingly dominate digital advertising and news distribution online.

headline: Election Law Provides No Firm Say on Legality of Trump Jr.’s Meeting
summary: Legal experts say it is far from clear whether Donald Trump Jr.’s 2016 meeting with a Kremlin-connected Russian lawyer crossed a legal line.

headline: NYC Teachers in Pool for Excess Faculty To Fill Classroom Vacancies in October
summary: Hundreds of New York City teachers who have been stuck in a much-criticized pool for excess faculty will be sent to fill classroom vacancies in October, under a plan that city officials announced Monday.

headline: Venezuela’s Symbol of Hope
summary: Opposition leader Leopoldo López is freed to house arrest.

headline: Another Manic Day at Wimbledon
summary: Rafael Nadal falls in a five-set marathon at Wimbledon, while Johanna Konta  and Andy Murray provide thrills on tennis’ most frenzied day.

headline: How to Squeeze China
summary: Force ruling elites to choose between North Korea and American colleges for their kids.

headline: The G-20: Another Vacuous Meet-and-Greet
summary: As the empty summit rituals unfolded, the great powers were busy making history.

headline: In Search of the Origin of the Jews
summary: For a long time, the biblical narrative held sway. Now scholars seek to distinguish historical fact from religious myth—if it is possible to do so.

headline: The Sport That Time Forgot
summary: In baseball, there’s no clock. It’s played only in the present.

headline: Pakistan Prime Minister Sharif Says He Won’t Resign
summary: Pakistan’s prime minister rejected calls to resign and will continue to fight allegations of corruption, aides said, after a criminal investigation found that he and his children were living beyond their means.

headline: J.C. Penney CFO Steps Down
summary: Edward Record, who joined J.C. Penney in 2014, will step down as chief financial officer but will remain in an advisory role through Aug. 7.

headline: Bond Market Predicts Low Inflation
summary: Investors aren’t giving up on the best-performing Treasurys, one sign that some think the recent bond market selloff could prove short-lived.

headline: Warren Buffett Gifts $3.2 Billion in Berkshire Hathaway Stock to Charities
summary: Berkshire Hathaway Chairman Warren Buffett has donated about $3.17 billion of shares in the company to five foundations, the latest contribution in a more than decade-long pledge to donate a portion of his wealth to charities and philanthropic endeavors.

headline: Not Your Standard Supergroup
summary: In ‘Sounds of Crenshaw Vol.1,’ Terrace Martin’s musical collective the Pollyseeds, blurs the lines between R&B, soul, funk and jazz.

headline: Dollar Little Changed Ahead of Yellen Report
summary: The dollar was little changed Monday, as investors weighed the possibility of higher rates in the U.S. against signs of tightening monetary policy abroad.

headline: Oil Prices Edge Higher
summary: Oil prices inched up with talk of production curbs in Libya and Nigeria and a sign of shrinking U.S. stockpiles leading to a small rebound from a recent slide.

headline: Germany’s Klöckner Hopes for New Steel Tariffs in the U.S.
summary: Germany’s Klöckner, a metals trading and processing firm, supports the Trump administration’s plans for additional tariffs on Chinese-made steel, said its CEO.

headline: Federal Appeals Court Upholds Former N.Y. Lawmaker’s Conviction
summary: A federal appeals court upheld the conviction of William Boyland Jr., a former New York state assemblyman serving a 14-year prison sentence for public corruption, saying the evidence against him was so overwhelming that errors in the jury instructions didn’t affect the verdict.

headline: Justin Turner’s Batting Is Way Better Than Average
summary: Dodgers third baseman Justin Turner entered July hitting .390 but was still initially passed over for the All-Star game.

headline: Wayne Rooney Returns to Everton, as Manchester United Signs Romelu Lukaku
summary: For Wayne Rooney, the wunderkind who grew up to be the top scorer in England national team history, the return to Everton is the perfect conclusion to a career that is grinding to a halt.

headline: Global Government Bonds Stabilize After Selloff
summary: Global government bonds strengthened, showing some signs of stabilization following a two-week selloff.

headline: Investors Beware: Bond Prices Are Threatening the Stock Market
summary: Rising bond yields threaten to undermine the case for holding expensive stocks, and shareholders should be worried.

headline: Chip Makers Feast on Phones Despite Slowing Sales
summary: Smartphones aren’t the growth market they once were, so the best play for investors is to find companies not limited to selling one chip per phone.

headline: Iraqi Leader Marks End of Pivotal Battle Against Islamic State
summary: Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi said his troops, backed by a U.S.-led military coalition, had recaptured the northern city of Mosul, driving Islamic State from its last major urban stronghold in the country.

headline: Obstacles to Getting Nonworkers Off the Couch
summary: For the first time in our company’s history, we cannot fill all of our job orders. How can this be in a city where more than one of every four of us are statistically living in poverty?

headline: Kennedy’s ‘Significant Nexus’ Rule Isn’t Much Help
summary: Can Justice Anthony Kennedy’s phrase “significant nexus” in(2006) really be described as a “standard”? Isn’t the phrase just so much opaque legalese?

headline: Cogeco Communications Expands U.S. Market Share With MetroCast Buy
summary: A Cogeco Communications Inc. unit has reached a deal to buy the MetroCast cable system for $1.4 billion, as the Canadian cable company expands its share of the U.S. market.

headline: New Fares and Fees Seen Lifting Airline Revenues
summary: U.S. airlines are raking in more per mile they fly a passenger for the first time in years, thanks to new fare classes and customized services that are squeezing more revenue from each customer.

headline: Exercise on Vacation: Essential or Pure Evil?
summary: A family holiday often means bad food and slothful habits. Jason Gay says it doesn’t have to be this way.

headline: U.A.E.’s Oil Company Eyes Partnerships, Listing Some Businesses
summary: Abu Dhabi’s state oil company said it was looking to publicly list parts of its businesses on the United Arab Emirates’ equity markets and would seek international partners as part of its drive to grow and expand operations.

headline: Abercrombie Loses Its Last Best Hope
summary: After two months of trying to sell itself, Abercrombie & Fitch is going it alone. A deal may have been its last chance for recovery.

headline: Sears Canada Holders Weigh Options
summary: The two largest shareholders of Sears Canada said that they have teamed to explore potential deals in connection with the struggling retailer as it winds through bankruptcy proceedings in Canada.

headline: CFTC Wants New Swaps Transaction Reporting Rules
summary: The U.S.’s top derivatives regulator on Monday said it plans to rewrite rules governing the reporting of swaps transactions in an effort to make data more consistent across firms and give regulators a clearer view of market conditions.

headline: For N.Y. Commuters, Day One of ‘Summer of Hell’ Starts Out Less Hellish Than Feared
summary: The first day of the “summer of hell” for the region’s commuters turned out less hellish than the governors of New York and New Jersey had feared.

headline: Pepsi Earnings: What to Watch
summary: Snack and beverage giant PepsiCo Inc. is scheduled to announce its second-quarter earnings before the market opens Tuesday.

headline: Summer’s Beach Read: A Complete Mystery
summary: Booksellers are enticing readers to take a chance on books wrapped in paper so the cover and title remain a mystery.

headline: Glitches Disrupt Trading in India, Indonesia
summary: Technical problems disrupted early trade on India’s largest stock exchange and Indonesia’s equities market, highlighting the vulnerability of the global trading system to such technology failures.

headline: Conference Board’s Employment Trends Index Fell in June
summary: A basket of U.S. employment indicators decreased in June, a potential sign of weakening job growth.

headline: Parkrun Lovers Ask: Why Pay to Run a 5K?
summary: A low-key weekly gathering of runners, already big in Britain, has developed a cult following in the U.S.

headline: Japan’s Trust in Abe Dwindles as Scandals Beset Prime Minister
summary: Japan’s prime minister has fallen into his biggest political trouble since taking power almost five years ago, with public support at a record low after allegations that he helped friends get favorable government treatment.

headline: What Would Gates Do? A Defense Chief’s Plan for North Korea
summary: Everybody who’s wrestled with the North Korean nuclear problem agrees on one thing: There are no good options for solving it. Few are more qualified to offer an answer than Robert Gates, the most seasoned senior U.S. national-security official of the last half-century, Gerald F. Seib writes.

headline: Photos: A Hot British Import: Free 5Ks
summary: Scenes from a recent Parkrun event in College Park, Md., where people gathered for a low-key run.

headline: Penn Station Track Repairs Begin
summary: Amtrak begins extensive repairs to tracks and signals in New York City’s Penn Station on Monday, prompted by two recent derailments and other problems with the station’s aging infrastructure.

headline: Why the Chip Rally Is Different This Time
summary: Times are very good in the chip business. In this boom and bust industry, that leads to the obvious question: are they too good?

headline: Five Things to Know About the Battle Against Islamic State in Mosul
summary: Iraq’s prime minister congratulated government forces ahead of declaring victory in a key city over Islamic State, but the extremist threat looms large elsewhere.

headline: Ripples Spread in Global Bond Selloff
summary: The global bond rout deepened last week, spilling over into the equity markets. Fixed-income investors have become jittery about major central banks sounding increasingly hawkish. The moves in German bonds were especially of note.

headline: A Key Borrowing Spigot Opens for Ford
summary: A handful of investors recently began extending short-term loans to an affiliate of Ford after more than a decadelong hiatus, signaling a potential thaw in relations between money funds and auto companies.

headline: China Is Driving Steel Prices Higher This Time
summary: At the recent G-20 gathering, world leaders railed against unfair trade in steel. But in China, there are signs that the drive against overcapacity is working better than in the past.

headline: Lawmakers Call on SEC to Reject Chicago Stock Exchange Sale
summary: Nearly one dozen Republican and Democratic lawmakers are urging federal regulators to reject the takeover of the Chicago Stock Exchange by a coalition that includes several Chinese investors.

headline: Finance Chiefs Want You to Use Plastic, Not Paper
summary: Companies are giving more of their employees corporate credit cards as they seek easier expense tracking and savings from suppliers.

headline: Facebook Again Cuts Price of Oculus Rift VR Headset
summary: Facebook for the second time in 2017 is slashing the price of its Oculus Rift to jump-start sales after a rocky first year for the virtual-reality device.

headline: Chinese Aircraft Carrier Liaoning in Hong Kong
summary: China's sole aircraft carrier made a port call in the city over the weekend.

headline: Rule to Protect Retirement Savings Likely to Lose Bite
summary: The Trump administration has raised questions about the impact of the fiduciary rule’s compliance costs, a sign that the rule meant to protect retirement savers from conflicted advice might advance without some of its primary enforcement provisions.

headline: Trump to Nominate Randal Quarles as Fed Bank Regulator
summary: President Donald Trump plans to put his first mark on the Federal Reserve by nominating Randal Quarles, an investment-fund manager and former Republican Treasury official, to be the central bank’s top official in charge of regulating big banks.

headline: Greece’s Antismoking Effort Has One Major Problem: Greeks
summary: The country passed a ban on smoking inside restaurants and offices in 2009, but citizens take pride in puffing where they please.

headline: Trump Regulation ‘Czar’ Cleared by Senate
summary: The Senate on Monday confirmed Neomi Rao, a conservative law professor and expert in regulation, to head a powerful federal office that reviews and assesses the costs and benefits of rules issued by agencies across the government.

headline: Iran Poised to Gain as ISIS Falls in Mosul
summary: Iraq’s U.S.-backed prime minister declared victory over Islamic State in Mosul on Monday, but Iran is shaping up to be one of the biggest winners in the struggle with Washington for influence in Baghdad and across the region.

headline: Senate Republicans Set Sights on Revised Health Bill
summary: Republicans returning to Washington said they hoped to produce a revised version of the Senate health bill later this week, though none of the expected changes so far appeared likely to win back sufficient support.

headline: What Did Hillary Know about Russian Interference?
summary: A congressional committee examines the Kremlin’s campaign to influence U.S. energy policy.

headline: Consumer Agency’s Arbitration Move Sets Off GOP Showdown
summary: An Obama-appointed regulator on Monday barred financial-services companies from requiring customers to use arbitration to resolve disputes, setting off a showdown with the Trump administration and congressional Republicans.

headline: Donald Trump Jr. Hires Lawyer and Pledges to Work With Congress
summary: President Donald Trump’s eldest son retained a private attorney on Monday and said he would work with congressional investigators who have sought his testimony as part of ongoing probes into whether the president’s campaign colluded with Moscow to influence the election.

headline: Oil Up? Oil Down? Blame the Algorithms
summary: As oil market moves confound analysts and longtime investors, many are pointing fingers at the rise of automated trading and algorithms, which they say are distorting the market.

headline: Department Stores Are Starting to Discount Cosmetics
summary: Desperate to get shoppers in the door, U.S. department stores have started to discount the one item they had long been able to sell at full price: cosmetics.

headline: States and Privacy Groups Push Back on Federal Request for Voter Records
summary: President Donald Trump’s election integrity commission faces growing resistance as it pushes states to provide personal details about every registered voter, including birth dates, political affiliations and the last four digits of social security numbers.

headline: Bipartisan Conclusions to Election-Meddling Probes May Be Elusive
summary: The two congressional committees investigating Russian interference in the 2016 election have committed to a goal that has eluded almost every major probe on Capitol Hill in recent years: bipartisanship.

headline: Trump’s Son Met With Russian Claiming to Have Clinton Intel
summary: President Donald Trump’s eldest son arranged a June 2016 meeting between top campaign aides and a Russian lawyer who has been linked to the Kremlin after being told she “might have information helpful to the campaign.”

headline: CMO Today: Newspapers Take on Google and Facebook; Fox News Maintains No. 1 Spot; UBS’s Content Rethink
summary: Here's your morning roundup of the biggest marketing, advertising and media industry news and happenings.

headline: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From WSJ
summary: Delivering up-to-the minute news, analysis, interviews and explanatory journalism on logistics, supply-chain management, e-commerce and more

headline: Investors Turn Attention to ECB Following Fed Moves
summary: The center of gravity in central banking is shifting away from the U.S. and toward Europe, where officials are considering winding down years of extraordinary economic stimulus.
